methods.dropReference: Drop a previously-retained reference to this referent.
methods.getWeakReference:
Get a WeakReference to this referent. This may be cached, or newly created.

:return: (java.lang.ref.WeakReference<? extends io.deephaven.db.util.liveness.LivenessReferent>) A new or cached reference to this referent
methods.initializeTransientFieldsForLiveness:
Package-private for Serializable sub-classes to use in readObject only.
 Public to allow unit tests in another package to work around mock issues where the constructor is never invoked.

Note: Java generics information - io.deephaven.util.annotations.@VisibleForTesting
methods.tryManage:
Attempt to add the specified referent to this manager.

:param referent: io.deephaven.db.util.liveness.LivenessReferent
:return: (boolean) Whether the referent was in fact added
methods.tryRetainReference:
If this referent is "live", behave as LivenessReferent.retainReference() and return true.
 Otherwise, returns false rather than throwing an exception.

:return: (boolean) True if this referent was retained, false otherwise

text:
This is a listener that writes down the indices that were updated on a given clock cycle, and then notifies another
 listener.  The intention is that you would have two of these, one for the left side and another for the right side
 of the join.  The ListenerRecorders are created before the MergedJoinListener, so that they are always fired first in
 the priority queue.  Once the MergedJoinListener is fired, it can examine the indices that were recorded into added
 and removed, and thus know what has changed on the left, and also what has changed on the right at the same time
 to produce a consistent output table.
